title: Monk Prasannachandra
subtitle: H.13 from SECTION H: STORIES DURING BHAGAWÄN MAHÄVIR’S LIFE

storyContent.tagHTML: One day King Prasanna was observing the clouds. Soon, all the clouds vanished from the sky. This helped the king realize the nature of life, which is like clouds and can end anytime. The clouds can also reappear, like the cycle of birth and death never ends. He decided to renounce his worldly pleasures and become a monk. He transferred his royal authority to his son, who was still a teenager.

Once, Prasannachandra, now a monk, came to Rajgrihi with Bhagawän Mahävir. He stood on one leg with his arms raised, engrossed in meditation outside the Samavasaran. Seeing his calm face, Durmukh, a minister of King Shrenik, became jealous and intended to disturb the monk's tranquility. He taunted him about leaving his young son to rule a kingdom now surrounded by enemies.

Outwardly, Prasannachandra was unperturbed, but inwardly, his mind grew restless. He visualized the frightened face of his young, helpless child and was mentally present at Pottanpur to protect his son. In his mind, he ordered his army to battle, and he himself came onto the battlefield, wounding and imprisoning all who threatened his son. This agonizing state of mind, full of violence and wrath, burned within him.

However, he heard the appreciative words of a humble layman thanking him for his exemplary lifestyle. This broke his trance, and the monk began to think: 'Whose son? Whose empire? Why do these earthly cares plague me? I must repudiate such feelings.' His thoughts shifted, and his mental enemies disappeared. His delusion was over, and the veils obscuring his knowledge were flung aside. Prasannachandra had attained omniscience.

While the monk was in his mental battle, King Shrenik had asked Bhagawän Mahävir where the monk's soul would go if he died. Mahävir replied, 'To the seventh hell!' Later, after the monk's thoughts had shifted, Mahävir said he would be reborn in the 12th heaven. Finally, sounds of joy were heard, and Bhagawän Mahävir announced, 'The monk Prasannachandra has attained omniscience!' He explained that the monk's destiny changed moment by moment with the state of his thoughts, from hell to heaven, and finally to liberation.

charactersData.name: Monk Prasannachandra
charactersData.description: A king who renounced his kingdom to become a monk. His story is a powerful example of how thoughts alone can create immense karma and how purifying them can lead to liberation.

charactersData.name: Bhagawän Mahävir
charactersData.description: The omniscient Tirthankar who could perceive the monk's mental state and explained the immediate karmic consequences of his thoughts to King Shrenik.

charactersData.name: King Shrenik
charactersData.description: An inquisitive king and devotee of Mahävir, whose questions help frame the narrative and reveal the changing karmic state of Monk Prasannachandra.

charactersData.name: Durmukh
charactersData.description: A minister of King Shrenik who, out of jealousy, taunted the meditating monk, triggering the monk's internal crisis.

charactersData.name: The Unnamed Layman
charactersData.description: A passerby whose words of praise for the monk's asceticism served as the catalyst for Prasannachandra to break his negative thought cycle.

events.title: An Epiphany
events.description: Watching clouds appear and disappear, King Prasanna realizes the impermanent nature of life.

events.title: Becoming a Monk
events.description: He renounces his kingdom, hands the throne to his young son, and becomes the monk Prasannachandra.

events.title: The Taunt
events.description: While meditating, the monk is taunted by the minister Durmukh about his 'abandoned' son and kingdom.

events.title: The Mental Battle
events.description: The monk's mind engages in a violent battle to protect his son, generating karma that would lead to the 7th hell.

events.title: The Shift
events.description: Overhearing a layman's praise, he reflects on his attachments and begins to purify his thoughts, shifting his destiny toward heaven.

events.title: Omniscience Attained
events.description: By completely purifying his thoughts and repudiating all attachments, Monk Prasannachandra destroys his obscuring karmas and attains Keval-jnän (omniscience).

quizData.question: What natural event prompted King Prasanna to renounce his kingdom?
quizData.answer: He observed clouds in the sky vanishing, which made him realize the impermanent nature of life.

quizData.question: Who taunted Monk Prasannachandra while he was meditating near the Samavasaran?
quizData.answer: Durmukh, a minister of King Shrenik.

quizData.question: What did Monk Prasannachandra do in his mind after being provoked?
quizData.answer: He fought a violent mental battle, leading an army to protect his son and his kingdom, Pottanpur.

quizData.question: If the monk had died during his mental battle, where would he have been reborn according to Bhagawän Mahävir?
What event caused the monk to stop his negative thoughts and start reflecting?
quizData.answer: He heard a humble layman express appreciation for his noble and difficult ascetic lifestyle.

quizData.question: After he began to purify his thoughts, where would the monk have been reborn if he had died then?
What did Monk Prasannachandra ultimately achieve at the end of this meditative session?
What is the primary moral of this story?
quizData.answer: Thoughts are incredibly powerful and can lead a soul to hell, heaven, or even total liberation (moksha).

graphicsData.title: The King's Epiphany
graphicsData.description: King Prasanna watches the transient clouds and realizes the impermanent nature of life and worldly power, inspiring him to renounce his throne.
graphicsData.imageAlt: King Prasanna looking up at a sky where clouds are dissipating.

graphicsData.title: The Malicious Taunt
graphicsData.description: While Monk Prasannachandra is deep in meditation, the jealous minister Durmukh whispers taunts to disturb his peace.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A meditating monk with a sneering minister whispering in his ear.

graphicsData.title: The Inner Battlefield
graphicsData.description: Though outwardly still, the monk's mind is a raging battlefield where he violently protects his son, generating karma that could lead him to the 7th hell.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A meditating monk with a transparent overlay showing a chaotic battle scene.

graphicsData.title: A Moment of Clarity
graphicsData.description: The simple, appreciative words of a passing layman break through the monk's mental storm, causing him to question his attachments.
graphicsData.imageAlt: The monk's face shifting from anguish to realization as he hears a passerby.

graphicsData.title: From Hell to Heaven
graphicsData.description: King Shrenik asks Bhagawän Mahävir about the monk's fate, learning how his destiny shifts from the lowest hell to a high heaven based on his thoughts.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Bhagawän Mahävir explaining to King Shrenik, with images of a hell and a heaven shown.

graphicsData.title: Attainment of Omniscience
graphicsData.description: Having completely purified his mind and destroyed all obscuring karmas, Monk Prasannachandra attains Keval-jnän, and celestial beings celebrate his liberation.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Monk Prasannachandra glowing with a golden aura of enlightenment.
